section.para: The element assert names a pattern that, if found to be false in any <m> in a dependent TAN-LM file, will return the enclosed message upon validation of the dependent file, along with an error or warning. Modeled loosely on Schematron <report>.
Used by: <body>
The element category creates a set of features that share a common grammatical trait such as gender, number, etc.
Used by: <body>
The element feature names, through its IRI + name pattern, a grammatical concept (e.g., plural, subjunctive, 1st person) that characterizes a language.
Used by: <declarations>

listitem.para: Included features must be written for every language declared by the current file.

example.programlisting: <head> <declarations ed-when="2015-03-03" ed-who="kalvesmaki"> <for-lang>eng</for-lang> <feature xml:id="quote-cl"> <IRI>tag:textalign.net,2015:morphology:option:quotation-mark-closing</IRI> <name>closing quotation mark</name> <desc>Examples: ' ''</desc> </feature> <feature xml:id="dash"> <IRI>http://dbpedia.org/resource/Dash</IRI> <name>dash</name> <desc>Examples: --</desc> </feature> <feature xml:id="dollar"> <IRI>http://dbpedia.org/resource/Dollar_sign</IRI> <name>dollar</name> <desc>Examples: $ -$ --$ A$ C$ HK$ M$ NZ$ S$ U.S.$ US$</desc> </feature> <feature xml:id="paren-op"> <IRI>tag:textalign.net,2015:morphology:option:bracket-opening</IRI> <name>opening bracket</name> <desc>Examples: ( [ {</desc> </feature> <feature xml:id="paren-cl"> ......... </feature> ......... </declarations> </head>

section.para: The element option refer to a feature.
If its parent is <category>, this element indicates a feature that is allowed in that area.

If its parent is <body> it markes a supplemental way to refer to the feature other than the assigned @xml:id. Useful for situations where a code requires a value that is otherwise disallowed by @xml:id, e.g., colons.
Used by: <body> <category>

example.programlisting: <TAN-R-mor TAN-version="1" id="tag:kalvesmaki.com,2014:tan-r-mor:eng:penn"> <body> <option feature="quote-cl" code="''"/> <option feature="dash" code="--"/> <option feature="dollar" code="$"/> <option feature="paren-op" code="["/> <option feature="paren-cl" code="]"/> <option feature="comma" code=";"/> <option feature="period" code="."/> <option feature="colon" code=":"/> <option feature="quote-op" code="``"/> <option feature="PRPSS" code="PRP$"/> <option feature="WPSS" code="WP$"/> </body> </TAN-R-mor>

section.para: The element report names a pattern that, if found to be true in any <m> in a dependent TAN-LM file, will return the enclosed message upon validation of the dependent file, along with an error or warning. Modeled loosely on Schematron <report>.
Used by: <body>
The element TAN-mor specifies that the TAN file contains definitions for the parts of speech for a language, the codes for those parts, and the rules for combining them. Root element.
Used by: none
The attribute code contains a string that can be used as an alternative code for a <feature>.
Used by: <option>

listitem.para: The value of @code must be unique within a given category
Codes may not duplicate or be a case variant of each other.
No code may repeat an id of a feature

example.programlisting: <TAN-R-mor TAN-version="1" id="tag:kalvesmaki.com,2014:tan-r-mor:eng:penn"> <body> <option feature="quote-cl" code="''"/> <option feature="dash" code="--"/> <option feature="dollar" code="$"/> <option feature="paren-op" code="["/> <option feature="paren-cl" code="]"/> <option feature="comma" code=";"/> <option feature="period" code="."/> <option feature="colon" code=":"/> <option feature="quote-op" code="``"/> <option feature="PRPSS" code="PRP$"/> <option feature="WPSS" code="WP$"/> </body> </TAN-R-mor>

section.para: The attribute matches-m asserts a pattern in the form of a regular expression that is to be used to check matches in codes in <m>s in a dependent TAN-LM file.
One of four tests for determining the truth value that will trigger the message in a <report> or <assert>
Used by: <assert> <report>
The attribute feature refers to a feature by means of its @xml:id
Used by: <category> <option>

tip.para: Schematron Quick Fix: Replace content of attribute with all valid values To see a list of all possible valid values, add any invalid content, then choose this quick fix to replace all content with every possible value.

example.programlisting: <TAN-R-mor TAN-version="1" id="tag:kalvesmaki.com,2014:tan-r-mor:eng:penn"> <body> <option feature="quote-cl" code="''"/> <option feature="dash" code="--"/> <option feature="dollar" code="$"/> <option feature="paren-op" code="["/> <option feature="paren-cl" code="]"/> <option feature="comma" code=";"/> <option feature="period" code="."/> <option feature="colon" code=":"/> <option feature="quote-op" code="``"/> <option feature="PRPSS" code="PRP$"/> <option feature="WPSS" code="WP$"/> </body> </TAN-R-mor>

section.para: The attribute context specifies that when a dependent TAN-LM file is validated and the condition for the parent <report> or <assert> is triggered by the value of a given <m>, the message should be returned only if the <m> has at least one of the features mentioned by @context.
Used by: <assert> <report>

The attribute feature-qty-test specifies a number greater than one indicating how many of the features in @context must be present for the condition to be true. This is useful for situations where it is desired to flag values of <m> that try to combine incompatible features.
One of four tests for determining the truth value that will trigger the message in a <report> or <assert>
Used by: <assert> <report>

listitem.para: @feature-qty-test must neither be less than two nor greater than the number of features in @context.

section.para: The attribute feature-test indicates one or more features that are used to check the truth value of a <report> or <assert>. When a dependent TAN-LM file is validated, this attribute returns true for any feature that is found in an <m> element, and false otherwise.
One of four tests for determining the truth value that will trigger the message in a <report> or <assert>
Used by: <assert> <report>

listitem.para: @feature-test may not begin or end with an operator
Operators must separate groups or feature refs.
Feature refs must be separated by operators | or ,
Feature references and parentheses must be separated by a pipe operator: |

section.para: The attribute matches-tok carries a regular expression that is to be used to check the truth value of a <report> or <assert>. When a dependent TAN-LM file is validated, if the pattern matches the resolved value of any <tok>, the value will be true, and affect whether a message is triggered in any <m> elements that share an <ana> ancestor.
One of four tests for determining the truth value that will trigger the message in a <report> or <assert>
Used by: <assert> <report>
